infoPage.heading: Course Info
infoPage.desc: Schedule, location, online/recording details, and class size.

cards.title: Schedule
lines: 45 hours (class + live) plus 12 hours extra live sessions
57 hours total, includes iOS/Flutter intro live streams; 4/6 holiday

cards.title: Location
lines: 7F., No. 131, Songjiang Rd., Zhongshan Dist., Taipei

cards.title: Live & Recording
lines: Join in-class or from home and review anytime

featuresPage.heading: Highlights
featuresPage.desc: Guiding you to craft Swift into multiple complete, launch-ready apps

items.title: Learn the latest Swift, iOS, Xcode, UIKit, SwiftUI
body: Powered by Apple’s newest tech: Swift 6, iOS 26, Xcode 26. Modern tools are stronger and easier to learn, so you skip the old pain. For Swift basics, see <link1>When you strive to learn Swift, the world helps you</link1>. (We focus on UIKit for today’s jobs; SwiftUI is covered later.)

items.title: Live streaming with unlimited replays
body: Join live from home or in-class with clear screens; recordings let you revisit every detail anytime, even after the course ends.

items.title: Build 10+ complete apps
body: Create e-book, drink-ordering, and food-log apps from scratch. (<link1>After finishing the drink-ordering app, Peter even buys you a drink.</link1>)

items.title: TA support: LINE DM for questions before/after class
body: Stuck? <link1>Message Peter via LINE/FB or book a chat an hour before class</link1>. Even after the course, he remains your lifelong iOS TA.

items.title: Extra 12 hours of iOS & Flutter intro live sessions
body: Core 45 hours aren’t enough, so we gift 12 more hours covering iOS and Flutter fundamentals.

items.title: Humorous, engaging teaching
body: Peter mixes lively examples with jokes to help you absorb concepts. (See <link1>students’ notes on the fun vibe</link1>.)

items.title: Thoughtful exercises and rich assignments
body: Fun in-class drills and homework keep you motivated; make share-worthy apps. See <link1>100 Swift iOS App puzzles</link1>. Thanks to <link2>designer partners</link2> and <link3>alumni who share their beautiful work</link3>.

items.title: Blog your learning journey
body: Reflect and grow by blogging your app-building path. Read <link1>iOS App writer training plan</link1> for the benefits.

items.title: AI-assisted learning
body: Use Xcode, Claude, ChatGPT, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, Antigravity, Codex, Windsurf, Cursor, Grok, Zed for explanations, assignments, debugging, refactoring, and annotation boosts.

items.title: Free Swift intro e-book
body: Discover Swift through playful examples and Xcode playgrounds, learning every corner of the language.

items.title: Midterm/final tests & REST API portfolio
body: Assess your skills with exams; career changers can build a <link1>REST API-integrated project</link1> for interviews.

items.title: Free advanced workshops & ongoing assignments
body: Post-course, <link1>we keep sending assignments</link1> and host <link2>advanced iOS workshops</link2> to sharpen your craft.

items.title: Master industry tools for portfolios and resumes
body: Use GitHub for version control; with GitHub, Medium, <link1>GitHub Pages</link1>, and CakeResume to build <link2>app portfolios</link2> and resumes.

assignmentsPage.heading: Students’ showcase projects
assignmentsPage.subtitle: See the design work from the advanced track.
assignmentsPage.ctaLabel: Peter Pan Swift iOS App Classroom

audiencePage.heading: Who it's for
audiencePage.description: Built for developers with coding background who want to level up iOS skills.
targets: You know other languages or some app basics and want full iOS development skills.
You want a second specialty after work—pursue iOS jobs, freelancing, or your own products.
College students building iOS app projects.
High school students adding app projects to their portfolios.

promises.title: A lifelong friend

promises.title: Free future course materials
promises.desc: Stay current with Swift/Xcode updates—long-term students get the latest materials for free.

promises.title: Free replays in class
promises.desc: Want a refresher or to see Peter again? If there’s a seat, you’re welcome back—many reunions await.

promises.title: 1:1 coaching for full homework
promises.desc: Submit every assignment and earn 3 hours of 1:1 coaching (valued at 3000 NT).

promises.title: Special aid for low income or unemployment

qaPage.heading: Top 10 iOS App Development Q&A
qaPage.description: Peter Pan answers the most common questions about learning and building iOS apps.

items.title: Keep leveling up
items.body: Ten weeks is just the start—self-learning is key. Each year’s iOS SDK keeps us happily busy. Keep practicing, and ping Peter on FB anytime if you’re stuck.

items.title: Jobs
items.body: Plenty of iOS roles in Taiwan; Peter knows many founders and can recommend you.

items.title: Freelance
items.body: Take on projects to sharpen your skills, grow your portfolio, and earn along the way.

items.title: Start a business
items.body: Publish your own apps, build downloads and ad revenue; a few launches make a standout resume.

items.title: 20% off advanced courses
items.body: Enjoy 20% off Peter’s advanced courses (excludes third-party collaborations). Learning never stops, and Apple ships new tech every year.

hero.title: Peter Pan's Swift iOS App Bootcamp
hero.subtitle: A dedicated Swift track for building iOS apps. Pages will be filled in next—this scaffold keeps navigation and layout consistent.

introPage.heroTitle: Peter Pan's Swift iOS App Bootcamp
heroLines: Learn the latest iOS App tech:
Swift, iOS SDK, Xcode, UIKit & SwiftUI,
Unlock jobs, freelancing, or your own startup!
learnItems: Build iOS apps on your own and ship to the App Store.
Learn the latest Swift, iOS SDK, and Xcode.
Build 10+ engaging apps using RESTful APIs, data storage, animations, and other common techniques.
Create apps that match your own interests.
Get fluent with the Xcode toolchain.
Design polished UIs with Storyboard, xib, UIKit, and SwiftUI.
Lay out apps that fit every iPhone and iPad screen.

signupPage.title: Apply
signupPage.description: Sign up via Google Form. Payment is by bank transfer—we'll send account details by email, so be sure to enter a correct email address.
signupPage.formCopy: Submit the form and we'll email you the bank details and next steps.
signupPage.hint: After submitting, please check your inbox.
signupPage.psText: If this is your first time learning to code, or you'd prefer to start from a gentler foundation, consider Peter Pan's course designed for absolute beginners:
signupPage.psLinkLabel: SwiftUI Foundation for Liberal Arts Learners
steps: Fill out the Google Form to reserve your spot.
Watch your inbox—we'll send bank details and confirmation.
Complete the transfer to lock in your seat.

video.title: Build an app in a song's time
video.description: Creating an app isn't hard—within one song you can craft a simple Little Prince ebook app.

plans.title: Student Rate
plans.subtitle: Students and graduates within one year
plans.note: Installment plan: 3,000 x3, every three weeks

plans.title: Job-Seeker Support
plans.subtitle: 3 slots, unemployed 3+ months
plans.note: Warm pack rate (2 slots, low-income or hardship): 100

noticeItems: Bring a Mac running macOS 15.6 or later. You don’t need an iPhone—Xcode provides simulators. If you need to buy a Mac, feel free to contact Peter; <link1>this course partners with Studio A for special pricing</link1>, and Mac rental options are available.
tuitionPage.noticePs: If your Mac can’t upgrade to macOS 15.6, install an older Xcode instead.

items.title: Getting close to Xcode 26
items.description: Learn the all-in-one app development tool, Xcode.

items.title: Modern app language Swift 6
items.description: Learn Swift fundamentals and advanced topics: optionals, type casting, computed properties, closures, protocols, extensions, and generics.

items.title: Storyboard, the UI wizard
items.description: Build stunning app screens with Storyboard—no code required.

items.title: Playground practice ground
items.description: A sandbox to practice Swift and experiment quickly.

items.title: E-book App
items.description: Create e-book style apps like The Little Prince or Tang Poems.

items.title: Auto Layout, Stack View, xib, SwiftUI, and code-driven UIs
items.description: Craft interfaces that fit every iPhone and iPad size with Auto Layout, Stack Views, xibs, SwiftUI, and programmatic views.

items.title: App architecture with MVC & MVVM
items.description: Understand the three pillars Model, View, and Controller (MVC), wire code to Storyboard with IBAction and IBOutlet, control Storyboard elements via controllers, and explore MVVM (model view viewmodel).

items.title: Multi-screen apps and data passing
items.description: Build multi-screen apps with navigation controllers and tab bars, implement common CRUD flows, and learn multiple navigation and data-passing methods (prepare, delegate, notification, closure, IBSegueAction).

items.title: Protocols, delegates, and data sources
items.description: Master the most important iOS patterns: protocol, delegate, and data source—across multiple SDK components.

items.title: ARC memory management
items.description: Manage object lifecycles and memory. Solve strong reference cycles with weak, unowned, and capture lists.

items.title: App lifecycle and multitasking
items.description: Grasp how an app is born, moves between foreground and background, and terminates.

items.title: Table view design
items.description: Learn table view patterns and UITableViewDiffableDataSource.

items.title: Camera and photo library
items.description: Implement camera capture and access photos from the device library.

items.title: Persistent data that lasts
items.description: Explore storage options: UserDefaults, file read/write, Codable for custom types, and Core Data.

items.title: Networking deep dive
items.description: Display web pages, call backend RESTful APIs with JSON parsing, upload data, use GCD, Result, async/await, and handle multithreading.

items.title: Grid photo wall
items.description: Master collection view techniques and UICollectionViewCompositionalLayout.

items.title: Animation basics
items.description: Animate movement, scale, fade, flip, rotation, and more eye-catching effects.

items.title: Maps and location
items.description: Show maps, get user location, and build share-worthy check-in features.

items.title: Package management with SPM & CocoaPods
items.description: Learn Swift Package Manager (SPM) & CocoaPods.

items.title: Apple’s latest tech: SwiftUI
items.description: Learn Apple’s latest capabilities such as SwiftUI & Widgets.

items.title: Testing and publishing your app
items.description: Ship to the App Store.

items.title: Firebase app development (bonus)
items.description: Use Firebase to build apps that access cloud databases.

items.title: Flutter basics
items.description: Introduce building foundational Flutter apps with Dart.

testimonialsPage.title: Testimonials
testimonialsPage.subtitle: Real voices from learners—unfiltered stories that walk alongside you through each step of the journey.
testimonialsPage.ctaLabel: Peter Pan iOS App Course Testimonials

items.title: Thanks to Peter Pan for Flying Me into the World of Swift
paragraphs: "I will do my best to take care of you all"—that was the promise Peter made in our class group after one session, and it stuck with me. He truly delivered: whenever I got stuck on homework, he'd help me through it. Once, after he taught delegates in class and I still didn't fully understand, he patiently explained it again on LINE in a different way.
Peter's course builds step by step. The first few lessons boost your confidence—teaching you how to create an ebook app without writing code, using Storyboard to design beautiful interfaces.

Then comes the main event: Swift syntax. Although programming can feel dry, Peter always sprinkles in jokes and great music to keep us relaxed. My focus tends to wander, but his warm humor always pulls me back.

Over those two months I followed Peter's course almost stress-free. On day one he said, "This course is only 45 hours—if you want to master Swift, you'll need two to three times that." I agreed, and I really wanted to learn well, so between classes I'd set aside a full day to review, practice, and do homework. Even when I understood the lecture, problems would pop up at home. I'd Google first; if that failed, I'd ping Peter on LINE—he usually solved in one sentence what I'd struggled with for hours. He says he's on call 24/7, but I only message him during the day…

items.title: Peter Pan iOS App Programming Course Review
items.author: Kiki
paragraphs: In Peter's class, his style is nothing like other cram-school teachers who lecture until you fall asleep and call it a win. Peter interacts with students, asking questions to reinforce memory. It makes me think—I was always afraid of being called on, yet answering wrong was no big deal, and the questions he asked me stuck. He's also kind of magical: he explains tough programming concepts so simply that sometimes it doesn't feel like learning code at all—once he finishes, you just absorb it.

Peter truly lives up to this. Beyond being a teacher, he's a friend—there's zero distance. Whenever you LINE him, he replies fast. I sometimes wonder if he sleeps only three hours a day and drinks SK-II.

Fifteen lessons! I not only learned to build apps but also unexpectedly made a group of classmates. We chat in a LINE group, help each other debug, suggest improvements, and talk about everything—even baking bread and honeymoons. It's amazing; the friendships don't end when the course does.

items.title: iOS App Programming: The Us That Came After
items.author: Sky
paragraphs: By chance I signed up for Peter's Swift course, and an unforgettable story began… On day one I could feel Peter's unwavering dedication to Swift—his passionate energy infused the room. That must be the magic Peter casts on students! His teaching is approachable yet deep, mixing multimedia into the materials so learning feels lively, not rigid. Students let their guard down and dare to ask questions, breaking traditional education norms—many issues get solved through communication. Peter's motto: no problem he can't solve. After each class I'd already look forward to the next. Although homework got progressively harder, I held on to the mindset of not giving up once I'd committed. Completing assignments helped me review; when stuck I'd ask in the group or go directly to Peter. Making friends in class was also fun—everyone's level is different, so you can learn from those strong in logic, absorb new info, and level up. Thanks to technology, connecting is easier than ever.

The story nears its end. All good things must part. After 2,700 minutes of class we go our separate ways, hoping parallel lines cross again someday. The us that came after will carry Peter's magic forward. If I had to put an expiration date on this magic, I'd wish for 10,000 years. As the saying goes: you don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great. Just do it.
